abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Emergency Services Support
            Project for West Bank and Gaza had the following ratings:
            the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was
            unlikely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that an operation
            focused on fast disbursement and without explicit
            developmental objectives is an efficient and effective
            vehicle to respond to emergency and crisis situations.
            Delegation of implementation responsibility to the relevant
            units in participating agencies and line ministries leads to
            move effective and efficient implementation. Close
            supervision, in particular through field-based staff, and
            flexibility in adopting the program to local realities. It
            is necessary to ensure that implementing agency staff
            understand Bank requirements for implementation. While an
            emergency project is focused on fast disbursement, project
            implementation should also include output and outcome
            monitoring indicators. Multi-Donor Trust Funds offer a more
            suitable arrangement for managing large donor-financed operations.
